# ∞-Categories and Stable ∞-Categories: Motivation and Development

## Introduction 
Infinity-categories (often **$\infty$-categories** for short) are a generalization of ordinary categories that incorporate *higher morphisms* – morphisms between morphisms, between those morphisms, and so on *ad infinitum*. In an $\infty$-category, composition and identities exist only *up to coherent homotopy*, rather than strictly. Intuitively, this means that typical algebraic or topological objects (like spaces or chain complexes) can be organized into a category where not only objects and morphisms are present, but also homotopies between morphisms, homotopies between homotopies, etc., are part of the structure【33†L83-L89】【24†L186-L194】. Every ordinary category can be viewed as a degenerate $\infty$-category (with no nontrivial higher morphisms), but $\infty$-categories vastly enrich the picture by encoding *homotopical* information that ordinary categories forget【33†L83-L89】. This framework emerged from a pressing need in fields like algebraic topology and derived algebraic geometry to handle situations where compositions are associative or commutative only up to higher homotopies, and where one must keep track of these higher-order coherences.

In modern terms, an $(\infty,1)$-category (the most common case) is an $\infty$-category whose $k$-morphisms for $k>1$ are all invertible. There are many equivalent models (simplicial categories, Segal spaces, etc.), but a convenient definition (due to Joyal) is that an $\infty$-category can be defined as a simplicial set satisfying the *inner Kan* condition (a *quasi-category*)【6†L87-L95】. This definition rigorously encodes a system of objects, morphisms, homotopies between morphisms, and so on, such that all familiar categorical laws hold *up to coherent homotopy*. A basic example is the *$\infty$-category of spaces*: objects are (say) CW complexes or simplicial sets, 1-morphisms are continuous maps, 2-morphisms are homotopies of maps, 3-morphisms are homotopies between homotopies, etc. – essentially the *fundamental $\infty$-groupoid* of a space, which captures its full homotopy type. In fact, **homotopy theory** itself can be identified with the study of $\infty$-categories: a motto is that *“a homotopy theory is an $\infty$-category”*【24†L186-L194】. Every Quillen model category or similar presentation of homotopy theory gives rise to an underlying $\infty$-category (by formally inverting the “weak equivalences”) that retains all the homotopical information but discards the arbitrary choices of fibrations and cofibrations【24†L186-L194】. This shift to $\infty$-categorical language allows us to work intrinsically with the *homotopy-coherent* structures that were only implicit or external in classical category theory.

In what follows, we delve into the motivations behind introducing $\infty$-categories and *stable* $\infty$-categories, and how they were developed to address shortcomings of earlier frameworks. We then discuss how stable $\infty$-categories refine the notion of triangulated categories, providing better handling of exact sequences and homotopy-coherent diagrams. Finally, we examine how these concepts form a unifying framework in modern homotopy theory – generalizing classical algebraic and topological $K$-theory and powering new developments in spectral algebra and derived algebraic geometry. Throughout, we highlight insights from Lurie’s *Higher Topos Theory* (HTT) and *Higher Algebra* (HA), which collectively laid much of the groundwork for $\infty$-categories in today’s mathematics.

## Emergence of $\infty$-Categories for Higher Homotopical Structures

The impetus for $\infty$-categories arose from the realization that many *natural phenomena in homotopy theory cannot be adequately described by ordinary categories alone*. In homotopy theory, one often works with objects (like topological spaces or complexes) and morphisms defined *up to homotopy*. However, the **homotopy category** – obtained by identifying morphisms that are homotopic – loses crucial higher-order data. For example, given two homotopic maps $f,g: X\to Y$, an ordinary homotopy category would consider $f$ and $g$ identical, whereas in an $\infty$-category of spaces one retains a *2-morphism* (a homotopy) connecting $f$ to $g$. Moreover, homotopies themselves can be compared via higher homotopies (3-morphisms), and so on. *Homotopy theory naturally produces “higher maps” and thus calls for a notion of higher category*【23†L626-L634】. In short, *“homotopy theory provides us with natural phenomena whose description requires higher maps, that is some notion of higher category.”*【23†L626-L634】 This understanding crystallized towards the end of the 20th century, as mathematicians encountered situations (for instance, in loop space theory or deformation theory) where classical algebraic structures were “too strict” and had to be replaced by *homotopy-coherent* analogues (like $A_\infty$-algebras, $E_\infty$-operads, etc.)【23†L518-L527】. Higher categories (and related notions like $\infty$-operads) were the eventual remedy, providing a rigorous yet flexible language to encode these hierarchies of coherences【23†L522-L528】.

A pivotal insight was that any *model category* (Quillen’s axiomatization of homotopy theory) actually presents an underlying $(\infty,1)$-category. In other words, the complicated apparatus of model categories – with its cofibrations, fibrations, and weak equivalences – serves to give a 1-category presentation of a genuine $\infty$-category that is the “true” homotopy theory【31†L155-L163】【24†L186-L194】. For example, the homotopy theory of topological spaces can be encoded by the model category $\mathbf{sSet}$ (simplicial sets with the Kan–Quillen model structure), but what it really *encodes* is an $\infty$-category of spaces (equivalently, the $\infty$-groupoid of spaces). By passing to $\infty$-categories, one can work directly with these objects and their higher morphisms without the detour of model-categorical machinery. *Every model category $\mathcal{M}$ yields an $\infty$-category $\mathcal{M}_\infty$ that retains only the homotopy-essential information (weak equivalences become actual equivalences in $\mathcal{M}_\infty$)*【24†L186-L194】. This paradigm shift, championed by Joyal, Lurie, and others in the early 2000s, vastly simplified many homotopy-theoretic constructions by making *homotopy-coherent relationships explicit and functorial* rather than implicit.

Parallel needs arose in **derived algebraic geometry (DAG)**, where one studies “derived” or “homotopy” enhancements of schemes, stacks, and other algebraic structures. Classical algebraic geometry often uses **triangulated categories** (e.g. the derived category $D^b(X)$ of coherent sheaves on a scheme $X$) to organize complexes of sheaves up to quasi-isomorphism. But triangulated categories, being ordinary categories, suppress all higher Ext-group data beyond exact triangles. As Toën–Vezzosi, Lurie, and others realized, a fully satisfactory theory of derived (or homotopical) geometry requires keeping track of those higher extensions and compatibilities — in essence, using *$\infty$-categorical* tools rather than just triangulated categories. **Higher topos theory** (developed in Lurie’s HTT) introduced *$\infty$-topoi* and *$\infty$-stacks*, which generalize Grothendieck topoi and stacks by allowing sheaves of *spaces* (or complexes) instead of just sets. In these contexts, $\infty$-categories are ubiquitous. For instance, to a derived scheme one associates an **$\infty$-category of quasicoherent sheaves** (really, complexes of modules) rather than just an ordinary derived category; this $\infty$-category carries information about all higher Tor and Ext relations. *Stable* $\infty$-categories (discussed below) become the natural home for derived categories in DAG, resolving limitations of triangulated categories. Indeed, Lurie notes that *“triangulated categories which appear naturally in mathematics are usually equivalent to the homotopy categories of suitable stable $\infty$-categories.”*【31†L228-L236】 In practice, whenever one has a triangulated category coming from geometry or topology (say a derived category of sheaves, or the stable homotopy category of spectra), one seeks an **enhancement** to an $\infty$-category that contains the missing homotopy data. Derived algebraic geometry is largely built upon such enhancements: *stable $\infty$-categories of complexes and spectra replace triangulated categories of complexes*, allowing for finer control and homotopy-coherent gluing of local data【19†L2235-L2242】. This shift has been crucial; for example, many delicate questions about duality, descent, and monoidal structures on derived categories become more tractable or even trivial in the $\infty$-categorical setting.

In summary, $\infty$-categories emerged from a broad recognition that **higher homotopies needed a home in category theory**. By extending categories to include morphisms of all orders, one can *encode precisely those higher structures appearing naturally in topology and algebra*【23†L518-L527】. Classical homotopy invariants and constructions (like homotopy limits/colimits, loop space machines, etc.) find a natural expression in $\infty$-categories. This new language unified disparate approaches (simplicial categories, DG-categories, model categories) under a single conceptual roof. As one practitioner put it, *$\infty$-categories are the “true” categories to consider, since they don’t lose information and (homotopy) limits and colimits have a well-defined meaning in them*【13†L137-L143】. 

## From Triangulated Categories to Stable $\infty$-Categories

One of the early triumphs of $\infty$-category theory was the clarification of the relationship between **triangulated categories** and **stable $\infty$-categories**. Triangulated categories (introduced by Verdier in the 1960s) are 1-categories equipped with an *auto-equivalence* (usually denoted $[1]$ or $\Sigma$) and a class of “distinguished triangles” $X \to Y \to Z \to \Sigma X$ that abstract the behavior of exact sequences in homological algebra. Triangulated categories had long been used to organize derived functors and spectra in a single framework. However, they come with well-known drawbacks: the triangulated structure is **not fully functorial** (for example, given a map of triangles one cannot always complete it to a morphism of triangles in a canonical way), and some higher coherences (like the `octahedral axiom’) are complicated to verify and use. In essence, a triangulated category is the shadow (homotopy category) of some underlying homotopy theory, and working only at the level of this shadow can obscure or even lose important data.

A **stable $\mathbf{\infty}$-category** is an $(\infty,1)$-category that captures the homotopy-coherent content underlying a triangulated category. By definition, a stable $\infty$-category $\mathcal{C}$ is an $\infty$-category that is *pointed* (has a zero object) and in which every morphism has a *fiber* and *cofiber*, with the property that *fiber sequences coincide with cofiber sequences*【6†L113-L121】. Concretely, being *pointed* means there is an object $0$ that is both initial and terminal, analogously to a zero object in an abelian category【6†L87-L95】【15†L2401-L2409】. A **triangle** in a pointed $\infty$-category is just a diagram $X \xrightarrow{f} Y \xrightarrow{g} Z$ equipped with a filler to $0$ (homotopically, a null-homotopy of $g\circ f$)【15†L2404-L2412】. The maps $X \to Y$ and $Y \to Z$ form a *fiber sequence* if $X$ is (homotopy) the fiber of $g$ (so $X \to Y$ is like a kernel up to homotopy), and dually they form a *cofiber sequence* if $Z$ is the homotopy cofiber of $f$ (like a cokernel)【15†L2415-L2423】. **Stability** demands that these two notions coincide: *in a stable $\infty$-category, every commutative triangle that is a homotopy pushout (cocartesian) square is automatically also a homotopy pullback (cartesian) square, and vice versa*【15†L2421-L2427】. Equivalently, the suspension functor $\Sigma: \mathcal{C}\to\mathcal{C}$ (sending $X$ to the cofiber of $X\to 0$) is an equivalence and provides a functorial loop-suspension symmetry. This axiomatically encodes a key property of stable homotopy theory: in the category of spectra (the prototypical stable category), fibers and cofibers agree and suspension is invertible【6†L89-L97】. Lurie succinctly describes triangulated categories as *“an attempt to capture those features of stable $\infty$-categories visible at the level of homotopy categories”*【31†L230-L236】. Indeed, *the homotopy category $\mathrm{h}\mathcal{C}$ of any stable $\infty$-category $\mathcal{C}$ is canonically a triangulated category* (with shift functor given by $\Sigma$, and distinguished triangles given by fiber/cofiber sequences)【6†L119-L127】. This fundamental result required considerable work in Lurie’s HTT/HA, but it formalizes the idea that *every naturally occurring triangulated category comes from a stable $\infty$-category*【31†L228-L236】. In particular, one can *construct classical derived categories as homotopy categories of stable $\infty$-categories*, resolving questions about the existence of “enhancements”【4†L49-L57】【4†L51-L55】.

**Why is the $\infty$-categorical enhancement worthwhile?** The answer lies in improved *functoriality, coherence,* and *clarity of universal properties*. Many of the ad hoc or opaque aspects of triangulated categories evaporate when one passes to stable $\infty$-categories. For example, in a triangulated category, a mapping cone of a morphism $f: X\to Y$ is only defined up to noncanonical isomorphism; in a stable $\infty$-category, one can *choose* a specific cofiber of $f$ (essentially the homotopy pushout of $X \leftarrow 0 \to Y$) and it is defined *canonically up to contractible choices*, meaning any two choices are related by a *unique* higher homotopy【17†L2460-L2468】. This **contractibility of choices** in the $\infty$-world is exactly the extra “homotopy-coherent” data that ensures functoriality. Thus, *cones (cofibers) in a stable $\infty$-category are functorial* in a way that ordinary triangulated cones are not【17†L2462-L2470】. As a consequence, various triangle constructions become simpler: for instance, the notorious **octahedral axiom** of triangulated categories – a complicated diagrammatic condition – emerges automatically from iterated pushouts in a stable $\infty$-category. In fact, verifying the octahedral axiom reduces to drawing a pasting of two pushout squares and observing it yields another fiber/cofiber sequence, with a suspension appearing naturally in one corner【17†L2471-L2479】. Intuitively, *the higher-dimensional homotopies in an $\infty$-category supply all “coherence data” that one must axiomatize by hand in a triangulated category*【17†L2460-L2468】【17†L2471-L2479】. Stable $\infty$-categories thus **“fix many of the problems”** in triangulated category theory【15†L2388-L2396】. They are in some sense *simpler*: once one has the $\infty$-categorical language at hand, the definition of a stable $\infty$-category (zero object + finite limits/colimits + fiber=cofiber axiom) is much more natural and compact than the list of triangulated category axioms (which include octahedrality as a separate axiom)【15†L2421-L2428】. As one expository source puts it, *“stable $(\infty,1)$-categories are a wonderfully practical replacement for triangulated categories that fixes many of the problems in their theory”*【15†L2388-L2396】.

Another major advantage is the handling of **exact sequences and homotopy-coherent diagrams**. In homological algebra, one juggles commutative diagrams that commute only up to specified isomorphisms; in an $\infty$-category, one can instead work with *commutative diagrams up to homotopy*, where a “homotopy” is a 2-morphism filling the diagram. For example, a *commutative square up to homotopy* in an $\infty$-category is a 2-simplex witnessing the homotopy-commutativity. Stable $\infty$-categories make heavy use of this: a **distinguished triangle** $X \to Y \to Z \to \Sigma X$ can be seen as a homotopy-commutative square with $0$ in one corner【15†L2406-L2415】. The relationship “$Z$ is a cofiber of $X\to Y$” is encoded by saying the square is a pushout (up to homotopy), and dually $X$ is a fiber of $Y\to Z$ by saying the square is a pullback – in a stable $\infty$-category these conditions coincide【15†L2415-L2423】. Because these diagrams live inside an $\infty$-category, one can further talk about *morphisms of triangles* (3-morphisms connecting two homotopy-commutative squares) and so on, something impossible in an ordinary triangulated setting. All this added structure ensures that **exact sequences behave much better**: they satisfy universal properties rather than just existence and isomorphism classes. In essence, stable $\infty$-categories provide an *enhancement* or *lift* of exact sequences to a homotopy-coherent context, where phenomena like mapping cones, shifts, and derived functors become functorial *and* compatible with higher homotopies.

The upshot is that whenever one has a triangulated category of interest – be it the derived category of an abelian category, the homotopy category of spectra, or the stable module category of a ring – upgrading it to a stable $\infty$-category yields a more robust and powerful framework. For example, **derivators** were an attempt to regain some of this lost coherence above triangulated categories, but $\infty$-categories achieve it more completely. Today it is common to say *“use a stable $\infty$-category instead of a triangulated category whenever possible”*, especially in research on homotopical and derived algebra. Indeed, many cutting-edge results (like in modular representation theory or in the theory of motives) assume the availability of an $\infty$-categorical enhancement to apply tools like homotopy limits or adjoint functor theorems which are not available in the triangulated world【13†L137-L143】.

## Unifying Framework: $K$-Theory, Spectral Categories, and Derived Geometry

Beyond providing cleaner foundations, $\infty$-categories – and stable $\infty$-categories in particular – enable a **unified perspective on algebraic and topological $K$-theory** and other invariants, bridging classical subjects. *Algebraic $K$-theory*, as introduced by Quillen, assigns to a ring $R$ (or more generally an exact category or Waldhausen category) a sequence of groups $K_n(R)$ capturing profound arithmetic information. *Topological $K$-theory*, in the sense of Atiyah–Hirzebruch, assigns to a topological space $X$ the groups $K^0(X), K^1(X)$ (and periodic further groups) classifying vector bundles. At first glance, these two theories have different flavors; however, $\infty$-category theory shows that **both are instances of the same construction applied to different stable $\infty$-categories**. In modern language, one can define the *$K$-theory spectrum* $K(\mathcal{C})$ of **any** small stable $\infty$-category $\mathcal{C}$, generalizing all earlier notions. This construction extends the classical $K$-theory of rings (via the stable $\infty$-category of perfect complexes over the ring) and also encompasses topological $K$-theory (via the stable $\infty$-category of vector bundles or perfect complexes on a space, suitably interpreted). The power of this approach is that it provides a *universal characterization*: roughly, *$K$-theory is the universal homology theory on stable $\infty$-categories that is additive on exact sequences*【17†L2507-L2515】. In fact, the use of $(\infty,1)$-categories has allowed mathematicians to formulate and prove a precise **universal property of higher $K$-theory**, analogous to how $K_0$ is the universal additive invariant of exact categories【17†L2507-L2515】. All the higher $K$-groups (and the entire nonnegatively graded $K$-theory spectrum) can be characterized by such a universal property【17†L2507-L2515】. This insight was elusive with earlier technology; it required the full higher-categorical framework (notably, Barwick’s and others’ work leveraging $\infty$-categories). Consequently, many difficult aspects of $K$-theory can be streamlined by working $\infty$-categorically: for instance, Waldhausen’s additivity and dévissage theorems, localization sequences, and multi-functoriality are naturally built into the $\infty$-categorical formulation. 

Concretely, if $R$ is a ring (or ring spectrum), one considers $\mathrm{Perf}(R)$, the stable $\infty$-category of perfect complexes of $R$-modules (finite complexes of finitely generated projectives, in the discrete case). Then $K_n(R)$ is defined as $\pi_{n}$ of the $K$-theory spectrum $K(\mathrm{Perf}(R))$. When $R$ is a discrete ring, this recovers Quillen’s definition; when $R$ is an $E_\infty$-ring spectrum (such as $KU$, the complex periodic $K$-theory spectrum, or the sphere spectrum $\mathbb{S}$), this gives the $K$-theory of that object. In particular, *topological $K$-theory fits into the pattern:* one can show (by deep results in index theory and Bott periodicity) that for a reasonable topological space $X$, the **complex topological $K$-theory** $K^*(X)$ is isomorphic to the *algebraic $K$-theory of the category of vector bundles on $X$*. In higher-categorical terms, $K^0(X)$ is the Grothendieck group of the symmetric monoidal $\infty$-category of vector bundles on $X$, and $K^{-n}(X)$ (which equals $K^0(X)$ for $n$ even, $K^1(X)$ for $n$ odd) can be obtained as well from that $\infty$-category (essentially because Bott periodicity implies a suitable stability). Thus, both algebraic and topological K-theory become instances of *“$K$-theory of a stable $\infty$-category”*. This unification is not just philosophical – it allows techniques to pass between algebra and topology. For example, some calculations of $K$-groups of ring spectra or schemes use topological methods (via the $\infty$-categorical description and tools like trace invariants), and conversely, topological $K$-theory gains perspective as one example of a noncommutative (or derived) motive. The language of **spectral categories** is often invoked here: a **spectral category** means a category enriched in spectra (i.e. each hom is not just a set or space but a spectrum). Spectral categories can model stable $\infty$-categories very well: in fact, *every (small) stable $\infty$-category is equivalent (in the $\infty$-categorical sense) to the derived ($\infty$-)category of some small spectral category*【34†L216-L224】. For instance, one can take a small skeleton of the $\infty$-category and endow it with a spectra-enriched Hom, yielding a spectral category whose homotopy category is triangulated. Many earlier “enhancements” of triangulated categories were given in terms of DG-categories or spectral categories; the $\infty$-category viewpoint abstracts all those into one theory. Importantly, *$K$-theory can be applied to spectral categories as well*, and because spectral categories model stable $\infty$-categories, this is no new information – just the familiar $K$-theory of the corresponding stable $\infty$-category. This consistency is part of the appeal: invariants like $K$-theory, *topological cyclic homology* (TC), or *Hochschild/cyclic homology* all extend naturally from rings to differential graded categories to spectral categories, ultimately landing in the realm of $\infty$-categories for their most general definitions. The modern theorem of Blumberg–Gepner–Tabuada, for example, constructs a symmetric monoidal $\infty$-category of small stable $\infty$-categories and shows that its hom-object is related to $K$-theory【32†L47-L51】; informally, the space of maps between two stable categories $\mathcal{A}$ and $\mathcal{B}$ in this meta-category is $\Omega^\infty K(\mathrm{Fun}^{\mathrm{ex}}(\mathcal{A},\mathcal{B}))$ (the infinite loop space of the $K$-theory of the category of exact functors between $\mathcal{A}$ and $\mathcal{B}$)【32†L47-L51】. This kind of result underscores how **$\infty$-categories provide a common ground where algebraic and homotopical constructions meet**.

Turning back to **derived algebraic geometry (DAG)**: stable $\infty$-categories are a cornerstone of that field. In DAG, one enriches classical schemes by allowing “derived” intersections (resolving singularities homotopically) and one replaces sheaves of rings by sheaves of *$E_\infty$-ring spectra*. For a derived scheme or stack $\mathfrak{X}$, one obtains a stable $\infty$-category $\mathrm{QCoh}(\mathfrak{X})$ of (derived) quasi-coherent sheaves on $\mathfrak{X}$, which is typically a symmetric monoidal presentable stable $\infty$-category. These $\infty$-categories *“replace triangulated categories”* in DAG, as noted in one survey【19†L2235-L2242】. By working with $\mathrm{QCoh}(\mathfrak{X})$ as an $\infty$-category, one can perform *homotopy limits and colimits*, talk about *monoidal structures and duality* in a homotopy-coherent way, and glue local data along covers using $\infty$-topos theory. None of this would be as straightforward with mere triangulated categories. Stable $\infty$-categories thus allow DAG to rigorously treat phenomena like *derived pushforwards/pullbacks* of sheaves (which are adjoint functors between stable $\infty$-categories, obeying exactness on homotopy limits), or to formulate **Tannakian duality** at the level of $\infty$-categories (as in Lurie’s DAG VIII). As a concrete example, Lurie’s *DAG I* paper “Stable $\infty$-Categories” showed that if $\mathcal{A}$ is an abelian category with enough projectives, then its classical derived category $D(\mathcal{A})$ can be realized as the homotopy category of a certain stable $\infty$-category $D_\infty(\mathcal{A})$ with a universal property【4†L49-L57】. This *derived $\infty$-category* retains information like actual chain homotopies between quasi-isomorphic complexes, not just their existence classes, and it supports constructions like totalizations and filtrations leading to spectral sequences in a functorial manner【4†L49-L57】. More broadly, *any time we “derive” a functor or a construction, we are in effect passing to an $\infty$-categorical setting*: one embeds objects into complexes or simplicial objects and then inverts quasi-isomorphisms (a homotopy theory), obtaining an $\infty$-category in which the originally non-exact functor becomes homotopy-exact【31†L262-L270】【31†L273-L282】. Thus, $\infty$-categories provide a universal language for *derived functor calculus*. 

Finally, it’s worth noting that **spectral algebraic geometry** – an even further extension where “rings” are taken to be $E_\infty$-ring spectra (such as Morava $E$-theories, etc.) – also relies on $\infty$-categories. For instance, a *spectral scheme* is defined via a functor of points on the $\infty$-category of $E_\infty$-rings, and its category of modules is again a stable $\infty$-category. In this way, $\infty$-categories act as a *unifying framework* that connects classical algebraic geometry, homotopy theory, and new hybrid areas like DAG. They allow one to speak about objects like *perfect complexes on a scheme*, *compact objects in a derived category*, or *localization sequences of categories* in a common language, and thus classical results (like Nisnevich descent in $K$-theory, or the Bass–Quillen conjectures) can be formulated and sometimes proven at this higher level with greater conceptual clarity.

## Impact on Modern Homotopy Theory and Higher Category Theory

The development of $\infty$-categories, especially through Lurie’s foundational works, has profoundly influenced modern homotopy theory and higher category theory – to the point that these fields now largely *operate in $\infty$-categorical terms by default*. **Higher Topos Theory (HTT)** provided the language of $(\infty,1)$-categories and $\infty$-topoi, enabling rigorous constructions of classifying spaces, homotopy sheaves, and derived stack quotients. For example, the notion of an **$\infty$-topos** (Lurie’s term) generalizes Grothendieck’s topos (a category of sheaves of sets) to an $\infty$-category of sheaves of spaces【19†L2233-L2241】. This was essential in defining objects like *Stacks* in a homotopical setting and proving descent statements needed in DAG. Concepts from classical category theory – limits, colimits, adjoint functors, monadicity, etc. – all have their counterparts (often more subtle) in $\infty$-category theory, and HTT developed these systematically. **Higher Algebra (HA)** then built upon HTT by studying $\infty$-operads and monoidal $\infty$-categories, giving a framework for homotopy-coherent algebraic structures (like $E_n$-algebras) and for *stable* $\infty$-categories in depth (HA begins with a thorough treatment of stability, exact functors, and spectra as the “free” stable category on one generator【6†L91-L99】【6†L95-L102】). The result is that today’s homotopy theorists freely talk about *presentable $\infty$-categories*, *symmetric monoidal $\infty$-categories*, or *colimits in an $\infty$-category of spectra* as a routine matter – notions all defined in Lurie’s work. The language is heavily used, for instance, in the solution of the **Cobordism Hypothesis** (which requires the theory of $(\infty,n)$-categories to make sense of fully dualizable objects and $n$-fold adjoints), in the theory of factorization homology and $E_n$-algebras (higher monoidal categories), and in the study of **stable homotopy groups** of spheres (via the sophisticated manipulation of the $\infty$-category of spectra and its subcategories of chromatic localizations).

In higher category theory itself, $\infty$-categories serve as the basic building blocks for yet higher categorical structures. Many results about $(\infty,n)$-categories for $n>1$ reduce to inductive or recursive structures built from $(\infty,1)$-categories. For example, an $(\infty,2)$-category can be modelled as an $\infty$-category enriched in $\infty$-categories, and so on. Thus the theory of $\infty$-categories (with $n=1$) is the gateway to the entire tower of higher categories. This has conceptual payoffs: one can now seriously pursue the idea that *“$\infty$-groupoids are the same as homotopy types”* (the Homotopy Hypothesis) as a theorem – indeed Kan complexes (∞-groupoids) model all spaces. Likewise, higher categorical generalizations of fundamental theorems (like Van Kampen, Giraud’s axioms for topoi, etc.) are being proved in this language. The synergy with **type theory** (as in homotopy type theory and univalent foundations) is another modern development: $\infty$-groupoids correspond to types, and $\infty$-topoi to certain models of type theory, bridging logic and homotopy theory.

From a big-picture viewpoint, $\infty$-categories and their stable variant have provided *common ground for formerly separate mathematical areas*. For instance:

- In **algebraic $K$-theory and motives**, a stable $\infty$-categorical perspective allows one to treat categories of complexes (in algebraic geometry) and spectra of topological origin on equal footing. One studies “noncommutative motives” by considering small stable $\infty$-categories as the basic objects, and $K$-theory is one of the fundamental invariants in this setting (alongside others like topological cyclic homology). The fact that $K$-theory satisfies a universal property in this world【17†L2507-L2515】 means one can identify maps between $K$-theory spectra and other functors by formal arguments, something that has led to new results (e.g. the theorem that *$K$-theory is the universal *localizing* invariant of stable $\infty$-categories*, proven using higher categories).

- In **homotopy theory**, classical constructions like *spectral sequences* can be derived from filtrations in $\infty$-categories of spectra or chain complexes. For example, a *filtered object* in a stable $\infty$-category gives rise to a spectral sequence abutting to its homotopy groups, and this can be developed internally to the theory (Lurie’s HA has an extensive discussion on filtered objects and spectral sequences in an $\infty$-categorical context【4†L53-L57】). This unifies and clarifies many spectral sequence constructions that were previously handled on a case-by-case basis.

- In **topology and geometry**, invariants like *topological modular forms (TMF)* or *elliptic cohomology* are naturally studied via categories of spectra with extra structure (e.g. $E_\infty$-ring spectra) and their module categories. These are all handled cleanly with $\infty$-categories. Entire new theories – like Lurie’s *elliptic cohomology via derived algebraic geometry* – rely on mixing stable homotopy theory and algebraic geometry in an $\infty$-categorical way (e.g. considering the $\infty$-category of $E_\infty$-modules over the *tmf* spectrum, which is a stable $\infty$-category of quasicoherent sheaves on a spectral stack).

In conclusion, the advent of $\infty$-categories and stable $\infty$-categories has provided mathematicians with a *powerful lingua franca* for anything involving homotopy or higher-order symmetry. As one commentator noted, if one can manage the higher categorical machinery, *“go for it”* – use stable $\infty$-categories instead of triangulated ones, since they are better-behaved and **“don’t lose information”**【13†L137-L143】. The initial investment in higher language is repaid by cleaner arguments and the ability to state exact universal properties. Jacob Lurie’s HTT and HA books have become standard references, laying out the theory that now underpins large swathes of homotopy theory, algebraic geometry, and beyond. The role of these concepts in modern research cannot be overstated: whether it’s formulating the cobordism hypothesis, classifying dualizable objects in monoidal categories, or constructing the latest generalized cohomology theory, $\infty$-categories are likely to be involved. They provide the **unifying framework** that mathematicians of today use to **“encode higher categorical and homotopical structures”** and to **navigate between the classical and the modern** – from ordinary categories and cohomology theories to the vibrant world of higher categories and homotopy-coherent mathematics【23†L634-L640】【19†L2235-L2242】.

The idea is that ''a homotopy theory'' is an $\infty$-category, and that every model category encodes a homotopy theory. Therefore, every model category $\mathcal{M}$ should give rise to an $\infty$-category $\mathcal{M}_\infty$ that ''is'' the homotopy theory which $\mathcal{M}$ encodes, and which as such only retains the homotopical data of the model category, throwing away non-homotopical notions such as cofibrations and fibrations.
